config.question: John Adams’s midnight appointees were typical of which of these?

answer_3.response: Political patronage was a burden for the new president. Although he controlled several hundred jobs, he refused to dismiss all the Federalists. Nevertheless, he acted quickly to remove the so-called midnight appointees, partisan selections that Adams had made after Jefferson’s election. To transform federal hiring into an undisciplined spoils system, especially at the highest levels of the federal bureaucracy, seemed to Jefferson to be shortsighted.
